conversation.content:
You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Object that is being bought/sold: X
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 30 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>,
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
<PROPOSALS COUNT> [add here (inclusive of current)] </PROPOSALS COUNT>
<my resources> [add here] </my resources>
<my goals> [add here] </my goals>
<reason> [add here] </reason>
<player answer> [add here] </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> [add here] </newly proposed trade>
<message> [add here] </message
```

Please be sure to include all.
You are Player RED.

<PROPOSALS COUNT> 1 </PROPOSALS COUNT>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 30 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> As my goal is to sell the resource for ZUP and it cost me 30 ZUP to produce, I want to make a profit from this transaction. I'll start by proposing a slightly higher price than my cost to see if Player BLUE is willing to pay that amount, leaving room for negotiation if necessary. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 35 </newly proposed trade>
<message> I'm offering one unit of X, which cost me 30 ZUP to produce. Considering the quality and value of this resource, I propose a trade for 35 ZUP. Let me know if this works for you or if you have a counteroffer. </message>

<other player message> I appreciate the offer and understand the quality of X. However, considering the market and my current budget, I would like to counter with 28 ZUP for one unit of X. Let's find a middle ground that works for both of us. </other player message>
<other player answer> PROPOSAL </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 28 </other player proposed trade>

<PROPOSALS COUNT> 2 </PROPOSALS COUNT>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 30 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Player BLUE's offer is below my production cost, so accepting it would mean making a loss. I need to counter with a price that is above my cost to ensure a profit. A compromise between the initial asking price and Player BLUE's offer seems reasonable. I will propose a slightly lower price than my initial ask but still above my cost to see if Player BLUE is willing to meet me halfway. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 32 </newly proposed trade>
<message> Thank you for your counteroffer. However, selling at 28 ZUP would result in a loss for me. To meet in the middle, I propose 32 ZUP for the unit of X. This price covers my production costs and allows for a fair profit margin. Please consider this offer. </message>

<other player message> I understand your need for a fair profit margin. I can increase my offer to 30 ZUP for one unit of X. This should help cover your production costs while keeping the deal within my budget. Can we agree on this price? </other player message>
<other player answer> PROPOSAL </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 30 </other player proposed trade>

<PROPOSALS COUNT> 3 </PROPOSALS COUNT>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 30 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Player BLUE's new proposal matches my production cost, which means I would break even with this deal. While this isn't ideal since I initially aimed to make a profit, it might be the best compromise considering Player BLUE's budget constraints. I would like to make a profit, but making a sale at cost is better than not selling at all. To maintain good relations and ensure future business opportunities, I am inclined to accept this offer. </reason>
<player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>
<message> Thank you for understanding my position. I agree to sell one unit of X for 30 ZUP, covering my production costs and ensuring a fair transaction for both of us. I look forward to future dealings with you. </message>

You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):

    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
